content: Thanks for responding! It sounds like your company has an awesome culture, and one that they actively foster to make a healthy happy work environment. The “culture” I’m referring to in this article is not actual work-place culture. It’s usually ill-defined, not practiced, and used to exclude people during hiring or to write-off failures within the organization after employee churn, “She wasn’t a good culture fit”. It is also generally ageist, so I’m glad to see that your start-up includes mature employees who are often left out of the start-up hiring pool. As we both know, their experience is invaluable. Thanks for reading and your awesome feedback!
